services.applications: Method utilizes directional RNA libraries to process poly(A)+ enriched RNA into NGS libraries. Suitable for proﬁling changes in gene expression for biological discovery. The project can involve understanding differences between control vs treatment, or proﬁling changes across time-course or developmental series. Projects often use multiple biological replicates, analyzed to provide precision in inference of gene expression changes.

pros: High sensitivity for mRNA
Accurate quantification of >98% of encoded mRNA
Cost-effective
Ideal for differential expression studies to infer gene regulation
notes: Misses a small fraction of lncRNA, histone RNA, and non-polyadenylated RNAs
Not suitable for degraded RNA due to 3' bias
Reference genome or transcriptome required for read mapping

reports: Extraction QC, Sample QC, Summary of Methods
Data QC / Sequence Data Pre-processing Summary
Mapped data(.BAM) ﬁles sample and related QC reports
Gene expression matrix (.csv/xlsx format) : Raw counts, Normalized counts
Sample clustering reports
Differential gene expression report
Functional enrichment reports (Gene ontology - Biological process, Cellular Component, Molecular Function & KEGG/REACTOME pathways)
Supporting visualization each step (PCA/UMAP plots, Heatmaps, Volcano plots, Functional enrichment gradient plots, KEGG pathview maps* )
add-ons: *KEGG Pathview maps for pathways selected according to the interest of the study

services.service_name: RNA-seq (Eukaryotic Poly-A | Non-Model Organism - De Novo)
services.applications: Designed for RNA-seq studies where strain variation or lack of a suitable reference genome necessitates de novo transcriptome assembly. Particularly useful for plant and fungal samples where reference variation limits accurate mapping. Suitable for projects characterizing isolates across treatments or developmental stages.

pros: Suitable for samples requiring reference genome creation
High sensitivity for polyadenylated RNA
Accurate expression quantification after de novo assembly
Suitable for evolutionary and ecological studies
notes: Higher computational complexity than reference-based RNA-seq
Not suitable for highly degraded RNA

reports: Extraction QC, Sample QC, Summary of Methods
Data QC / Sequence Data Pre-processing Summary
QC reports, mapping summary, alignment summary, and de novo assembly statistics
Gene expression matrix (.csv/.xlsx): Raw counts, Normalized counts
Sample clustering reports
Differential gene expression report
Functional enrichment reports (Gene Ontology: Biological Process, Cellular Component, Molecular Function; KEGG and REACTOME pathways)
Supporting visualizations (PCA/UMAP plots, Heatmaps, Volcano plots, Functional enrichment gradient plots, KEGG Pathview maps*)
add-ons: KEGG Pathview maps for pathways selected according to the interest of the study
Transcriptome secondary metabolite mapping

services.applications: Suitable for comprehensive profiling of total RNA when analysis requires non-polyadenylated RNA species such as histone RNA, tRNA, lncRNA, and other RNA classes. The method uses rRNA depletion followed by directional RNA library preparation for NGS profiling. Total RNA sequencing is suitable for partially degraded RNA samples where RIN values do not meet criteria for poly(A)-based RNA profiling.

pros: Profiles total RNA including tRNA, lncRNA, and other non-polyadenylated RNAs
Suitable for partially degraded RNA
Provides broad transcriptome coverage
Enables isoform-level quantification using a reference genome
notes: Increased data complexity requiring higher sequencing depth
rRNA depletion efficiency impacts data quality

process_map: Gene, Transcript, lncRNA and Other RNA Quantification

reports: Extraction QC, Sample QC, Summary of Methods
Data QC / Sequence Data Pre-processing Summary
Raw sequencing data and raw read counts across all samples
Normalized read counts with sample grouping, clustering and QC plots (PCA, heatmap of top 2000 variant genes, dendrogram, sample correlation plots)
Differential expression reports for each comparison with corresponding volcano plots
Functional over-representation (enrichment) analysis per comparison with gradient bar plots for top 20 enriched GO terms (BP, MF, CC) and Reactome pathways
Raw and normalized counts of lncRNA for each sample with clustering and QC plots (PCA, heatmap of top 2000 variant genes, dendrogram, sample correlation plots)
Differential expression reports of known lncRNA for each comparison with volcano plots
Functional over-representation analysis for direct lncRNAs, cis-target mRNAs, and mRNAs interacting with lncRNAs, including supporting plots and tables
add-ons: Identiﬁcation of co - expressed mRNA and lncRNA followed by visualization Interaction network for lncRNA and mRNA.
Detection of Known and Novel circNAs with the supporting plots
circRNA expression analysis per comparison. Volcano plot and Heatmap of Signiﬁcant Circular RNAs
Summary statistics of Circular RNA and their supporting plots
Analysis - ASE (Alternative Splicing Event) per and Identiﬁcation of Novel splice variants
Overall Volcano plot for Differentially Expressed ASE and Individual Volcano plots for each events
Scatter plots for showing splicing levels (percent - spliced -in, PSI) between two conditions.

Gene ontology - Biological process, Molecular Function and Cellular components (overrepresentation analysis using enriched genes of top 10 differential alternative splicing events and their supporting plot.

services.applications: Bacterial RNA-seq is used to profile gene expression changes upon treatment or environmental perturbation. The workflow enables sensitive detection of differential gene expression using microbial rRNA depletion followed by directional RNA library preparation for NGS. While reference-based mapping enables accurate alignment, de novo assembly may be required to discover novel transcripts acquired through horizontal gene transfer or encoded on plasmids or episomes.

pros: Comprehensive coverage of coding bacterial RNAs
High-accuracy reference-based alignment
Suitable for operon- and pathway-level analysis
Enables condition-specific expression profiling
notes: Requires high-quality RNA for effective rRNA depletion
Reference genome quality impacts read mapping accuracy
Not suitable for mixed or highly complex samples
Reference-based mapping may miss novel transcripts, requiring de novo assembly

reports: Extraction QC, Sample QC, Summary of Methods
Data QC / Sequence Data Pre-processing Summary
Raw and QC-trimmed sequencing data (.FASTQ files) with QC reports per sample
Mapped data (.BAM files) with related QC reports
Gene expression matrix (.csv/.xlsx): Raw counts and Normalized counts
Sample clustering reports
Differential gene expression report
Functional enrichment reports (Gene Ontology: Biological Process, Cellular Component, Molecular Function; KEGG and REACTOME pathways)
Supporting visualizations (PCA, UMAP, t-SNE plots, Heatmaps, Volcano plots, Functional enrichment gradient plots, KEGG Pathview maps)

services.applications: Cost-effective, high-throughput RNA sequencing for gene expression profiling from blood samples using 3' end-tag RNA-seq. Optimized for large-scale studies requiring robust gene-level expression quantification from whole blood. The workflow involves globin mRNA removal followed by directional RNA library preparation. Particularly suitable for whole-blood transcriptome profiling in biomarker discovery studies, where globin depletion improves gene profiling and enhances coverage of low-abundance blood transcripts.

pros: Cost-effective for large sample numbers
Optimized sequencing requirements focused on genes of interest
Robust gene-level quantification
High reproducibility across samples
notes: Limited information on splice variants and isoforms
Dependent on availability and quality of a reference genome

supported_sample_types: Stabilized blood (PAXgene, Tempus, or similar tubes)

reports: Extraction QC, Sample QC, Summary of Methods
Data QC / Sequence Data Pre-processing Summary
Raw and QC-trimmed sequencing data (.FASTQ files) with QC reports per sample
Mapped data (.BAM files) with related QC reports
Gene expression matrix (.csv/.xlsx): Raw counts and Normalized counts
Sample clustering reports
Differential gene expression report
Functional enrichment reports (Gene Ontology: Biological Process, Cellular Component, Molecular Function; KEGG and REACTOME pathways)
Supporting visualizations (PCA/UMAP plots, Heatmaps, Volcano plots, Functional enrichment gradient plots, KEGG Pathview maps*)
add-ons: KEGG Pathview maps for pathways selected according to the interest of the study

services.service_name: RNA-seq (FFPE | Human / Mouse / Rat | With Reference Genome)
services.applications: Optimized RNA sequencing for formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) human, mouse, and rat samples, enabling reliable gene expression profiling from degraded and fragmented RNA. Designed for translational, clinical, and retrospective studies using well-annotated reference genomes.

pros: Compatible with degraded and fragmented RNA
Enables analysis of valuable archived samples
Robust gene-level expression quantification
Reference-based alignment ensures accuracy
Ideal for clinical and translational research
notes: Limited isoform and splice-variant detection
Lower library complexity compared to fresh-frozen samples
Data quality dependent on fixation and storage conditions
Reference-genome dependent

input_amount.description: 5 μm x 4 FFPE tissue sections yielding approximately 100 ng RNA

process_map: Ribosomal RNA Depletion and Directional Library Preparation

reports: Extraction QC, Sample QC, Summary of Methods
Raw data QC reports
Gene expression matrix (.csv/.xlsx): Raw counts and Normalized counts
Sample clustering reports
Differential gene expression report
Functional enrichment reports (Gene Ontology: Biological Process, Cellular Component, Molecular Function; KEGG and REACTOME pathways)
Supporting visualizations (PCA/UMAP plots, Heatmaps, Volcano plots, Functional enrichment gradient plots, KEGG Pathview maps*)
add-ons: KEGG Pathview maps for pathways selected according to the interest of the study
Splice isoform analysis
Fusion gene detection
lncRNA profiling

services.applications: Discovery transcriptome sequencing designed to generate multiple layers of information from FFPE tumor samples. The workflow is optimized for fragmented RNA while maintaining broad transcript coverage. Multiple libraries are multiplexed to mitigate FFPE-associated biases. Advanced computational analysis enables detection of gene fusions, alternative splice forms, tumor signatures, immune cell composition, and neoantigen-related features from RNA-seq data.

pros: Discovery-focused research from archived FFPE samples
Broad transcriptome coverage from fragmented RNA
Optimized library design to address FFPE-associated biases
Reference-based analysis for high-confidence results
Ideal for in-depth tumor profiling
notes: RNA fragmentation may impact detection of low-abundance transcripts
Variability in FFPE sample quality affects discovery outcomes
Reference-genome dependent analysis

reports: Extraction QC, Sample QC, Summary of Methods
Data QC / Sequence Data Pre-processing Summary
Raw and QC-trimmed sequencing data (.FASTQ files) with QC reports per sample
Mapped data (.BAM files) with related QC reports
Gene expression matrix (.csv/.xlsx): Raw counts and Normalized counts
Gene expression report including FPKM and TPM values
Functional enrichment reports (Gene Ontology: Biological Process, Cellular Component, Molecular Function; KEGG and REACTOME pathways)
UMAP plots, Heatmaps, Volcano plots, Functional enrichment gradient plots
KEGG Pathview maps for selected pathways
Splice forms, transcript-level results, and fusion RNA reports
add-ons: Tumor signature analysis
Immune profiling
Mutation detection from RNA-seq data

services.applications: Designed for multistage transcriptomic profiling of host-pathogen interactions in plant-fungal or plant-bacterial systems. The workflow enables simultaneous analysis of host and pathogen gene expression changes during infection or treatment, across single or multiple time points. For fungal pathogens, directional poly(A)-enriched libraries are generated. For bacterial pathogens, total RNA sequencing with dual ribosomal RNA depletion is applied prior to directional library preparation.

pros: Simultaneous profiling of host and pathogen transcriptomes
Captures dynamic interaction and response signatures
Enables cross-species regulatory pathway discovery
Efficient utilization of samples and sequencing depth
Ideal for discovery-driven and hypothesis-driven studies
notes: Requires careful library design and sufficient sequencing depth
Host RNA often dominates total reads
Accurate reference genomes or transcriptomes are required
Data analysis and biological interpretation are complex

fungal_host_workflow: Host Reference (De novo Assembly and Annotation)

reports: Extraction QC, Sample QC, Summary of Methods
Data QC / Sequence Data Pre-processing Summary
Raw and QC-trimmed sequencing data (.FASTQ files) with QC reports per sample (reference-based; protein-coding genes only)
Mapped data (.BAM files) with related QC reports for both host and pathogen
Separate gene expression matrices for host and pathogen (.csv/.xlsx): Raw counts and Normalized counts
Sample clustering reports
Differential gene expression reports for host and pathogen
Functional enrichment reports (Gene Ontology: Biological Process, Cellular Component, Molecular Function; KEGG and REACTOME pathways)
Host-pathogen interaction analysis using WGCNA networks
Protein-protein interaction network analysis
Supporting visualizations (PCA/UMAP plots, Heatmaps, Volcano plots, Functional enrichment gradient plots, KEGG Pathview maps and additional plots)
*Reference genome or transcriptome must be available for the host and pathogen organisms
add-ons: KEGG Pathview maps for pathways selected according to the interest of the study

services.applications: Designed for plant and microbial systems where significant variation across ecotypes or strains limits the use of existing reference genomes. This service generates a de novo transcriptome assembly that is annotated and used for differential gene expression analysis. Directional RNA libraries prepared from poly(A)+ RNA or total RNA enable both transcript discovery and comprehensive gene expression profiling, supporting studies in emerging and understudied species.

pros: No reference genome required
Enables discovery of novel genes and transcripts
Broad transcriptome coverage
Suitable for emerging and understudied species
Flexible across diverse plant and microbial systems
notes: Assembly quality depends on RNA quality and sequencing depth
Higher computational complexity than reference-based RNA-seq
Isoform resolution may vary across organisms

reports: Extraction QC, Sample QC, Summary of Methods
Data QC / Sequence Data Pre-processing Summary
Raw and QC-trimmed sequencing data (.FASTQ files) with QC reports per sample
De novo assembly statistics and annotation summaries
Gene expression matrix (.csv/.xlsx): Raw counts and Normalized counts
Sample clustering reports
Differential gene expression report
Functional enrichment reports (Gene Ontology: Biological Process, Cellular Component, Molecular Function; KEGG and REACTOME pathways)
Supporting visualizations (PCA/UMAP plots, Heatmaps, Volcano plots, Functional enrichment gradient plots, KEGG Pathview maps and additional plots)
add-ons: KEGG Pathview maps for pathways selected according to the interest of the study

services.applications: Targeted amplification and next-generation sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene V3-V4 hypervariable regions to profile bacterial communities in human gut samples. This applied genomics approach enables accurate taxonomic characterization and comparative analysis of gut microbiome composition across biological conditions. The method is cost-effective and scalable, ideal for cohort-based studies focused on microbial diversity, beta-diversity, and treatment-driven changes in well-characterized metagenomes with established reference datasets.

pros: High-resolution profiling of gut bacterial communities
Cost-effective microbiome analysis
Suitable for large cohort studies
Robust taxonomic classification
Ideal for comparative gut microbiome studies
notes: Limited to bacterial community profiling
Species- and genus-level resolution may vary for V3-V4 regions
Functional insights are predictive rather than direct
Results influenced by sample handling and storage conditions

sample_handling_notes: Fresh or frozen samples are not accepted

reports: Sample and library QC reports with summary
Methodology and workflow summary
Taxonomic diversity and abundance analysis using SILVA, Greengenes, and 16S-NCBI reference databases
Read clustering and rarefaction analysis
Species and genus-level diversity metrics (Shannon, Simpson, Chao indices)
PCA and PCoA plots
Differential abundance heatmaps
KRONA charts
Predicted microbial pathway analysis (optional)

services.applications: Full-length 16S rRNA gene (whole amplicon) sequencing for high-resolution profiling of bacterial communities. By capturing the complete 16S gene, this approach enables more accurate genus- and species-level classification compared to partial-fragment methods such as V3-V4 sequencing. Long-amplicon reads improve confidence in species discovery, microbial pathway inference, and alpha-diversity estimation. Applicable to well-referenced metagenomes such as the human gut, as well as environmental and gut-derived clinical samples.

pros: Superior 16S resolution for diversity analysis
Enhanced species-level identification
Reduced primer-region bias compared to short-amplicon methods
Ideal for detailed microbiome profiling
Suitable for cohort-based and longitudinal studies where species resolution is required
notes: Focused on bacterial community analysis
Functional insights are predictive rather than direct
Species-level resolution depends on completeness of reference databases
Sensitive to DNA quality and extraction/amplification efficiency

process_map: Reference Matching using RDP and SILVA
Diversity Analysis and Microbial Pathway Prediction

reports: Sample and library QC reports
Methodology and workflow summary
Raw data QC and processing reports
Read clustering, reference matching, and rarefaction analysis
Species and genus identification with Shannon and Simpson diversity indices
Differential taxonomic abundance analysis with heatmaps
KRONA charts
Predicted microbial pathway analysis (optional)

services.applications: Integrated amplicon sequencing approach for comprehensive profiling of mixed microbial communities within a single study. Bacterial communities are characterized using 16S rRNA gene sequencing, while fungal communities are profiled using ITS (ITS1/ITS2) or 18S rRNA regions. This method enables simultaneous assessment of bacterial-fungal composition, diversity, and co-occurrence patterns across biological or environmental conditions. Long-amplicon sequencing allows typing of microbial, fungal, and plant components present in a microbiome. Suitable for time-course and treatment-dependent studies, and for samples with high host DNA or limited microbial DNA, as well as pilot studies preceding whole-genome, metagenome, or metatranscriptome analyses.

pros: Simultaneous profiling of bacterial and fungal communities
Enables cross-kingdom interaction analysis
Improved ecological and functional interpretation of microbiomes
Suitable for complex and heterogeneous microbiome studies
notes: Based on targeted marker-gene sequencing
Functional insights are predictive rather than direct
Taxonomic resolution depends on reference database completeness
Sensitive to sample quality and PCR inhibitors
ITS markers may not detect all fungal taxa with equal efficiency

process_map: 16S rDNA and ITS Library Preparation and QC

reports: Sample QC, Library QC, and Summary of Methods
Data QC and sequence data preprocessing summary
16S-based bacterial species typing and abundance profiles
ITS-based fungal species identification and abundance profiles
Rarefaction plots
Species summaries and count tables
Diversity metrics including Shannon and Simpson indices
Beta diversity analysis with differential heatmaps and PCA plots (for time-course or treatment-based studies)

services.applications: Shotgun whole metagenome sequencing using Oxford Nanopore Technologies to comprehensively profile the genetic content of complex microbial communities. Long-read sequencing enables improved genome assembly, strain-level resolution, and detection of structural variants, mobile genetic elements, plasmids, phages, and antimicrobial resistance genes. This approach supports bacteria, archaea, fungi, and viruses within a single experiment. Whole metagenome sequencing enables discovery of novel microbial genomes, genes, and enzymes from complex or unculturable microbiomes, and supports functional pathway annotation and mechanistic inference. Samples with high host DNA background may require host depletion, enrichment strategies, or additional sequencing depth to achieve adequate rarefaction.

pros: Long reads enable improved metagenome assembly
Enhanced strain- and species-level resolution
Detection of plasmids, phages, episomes, and structural variants
Suitable for complex and mixed microbial communities
Enables comprehensive functional and pathway-level profiling
notes: Sensitive to sample preparation quality and inhibitors
Requires high-quality, high-molecular-weight DNA
Bioinformatics analysis is computationally intensive
Sequencing depth impacts genome recovery
Lower sensitivity for beta-diversity compared to 16S amplicon methods
For infected samples, microbiome amplicon analysis is recommended prior to whole metagenome sequencing

instrumentation.expected_output: 5-10 GB of long-read data per sample

reports: Sample QC, library QC, and method summary
Raw data QC, adapter trimming, and preprocessing reports
Metagenome assembly summary
Gene annotation and species/genus/strain-level classification using reference databases
Identification of phages, episomes, and viral DNA with abundance and rarefaction profiling
Alpha diversity analysis (Shannon and Simpson indices)
Beta diversity and inter-sample diversity analysis for multi-sample studies
Host DNA is treated as contamination and should ideally be removed during sample preparation

services.applications: Shotgun sequencing of total community RNA to capture actively expressed genes from complex microbial communities. Metatranscriptomics reveals real-time functional activity, metabolic pathways, and regulatory responses by profiling community-wide transcripts. The workflow typically includes rRNA depletion followed by cDNA library preparation and long-read sequencing. This approach enables discovery of condition-specific enzymes and novel pathways activated during processes such as biotransformation and material degradation. Time-course profiling supports differential expression analysis to infer metabolic switches and dynamic regulatory changes. Long-read cDNA sequencing minimizes assembly artifacts arising from closely related species in mixed microbial communities.

pros: Captures actively expressed microbial functions
Reveals real-time metabolic and regulatory activity
Complements whole metagenome sequencing
Suitable for functional ecology and systems biology studies
Enables condition-specific pathway and gene expression analysis
notes: RNA is highly sensitive to degradation
Effective rRNA depletion may be required
Sensitive to sample preparation quality and inhibitors
In host-microbial systems, only expressed genomes are profiled unlike DNA-based metagenomics

instrumentation.expected_output: 10-15 GB of long-read data per sample

process_map: Host-Microbial cDNA Library Preparation with Methylation Handling
Differential Expression Analysis (for time-course or multi-condition studies)

reports: Sample QC, Library QC, and Summary of Methods
Data QC and sequence data pre-processing summary
Metatranscriptome assembly results
Gene identification with species and reference-based abundance estimates
Transcript-to-pathway mapping and functional annotation
Differential expression analysis for time-course or multi-condition experiments to assess modulation of transcripts and species abundances

services.applications: High-coverage whole genome resequencing of eukaryotic organisms followed by alignment to a reference genome for comprehensive variant discovery. This approach enables accurate identification of single nucleotide variants (SNVs), insertions and deletions (InDels), copy number variations (CNVs), and structural variants across the genome. Long-read sequencing improves detection of large structural variants and complex genomic regions. Whole genome resequencing provides an unbiased discovery platform for genetic analysis, rare SNP discovery, population structure analysis, and identification of coding and non-coding genomic variations. Suitable for trait mapping, disease association studies, and evolutionary genomics.

pros: High-resolution, genome-wide variant detection
Accurate comparison against a reference genome
Suitable for population genetics and evolutionary studies
Scalable across small to large eukaryotic genomes
Supports trait mapping and disease association analysis
notes: Requires a high-quality reference genome
Structural variant detection benefits from higher coverage, especially with long-read sequencing
Polyploid genomes require increased sequencing depth

coverage_guidelines.long_read: Long-read coverage optimized for structural variant detection

reports: Sample QC, Library QC, and Summary of Methods
Data QC, trimming, pre-processing, and adapter trimming reports
Reference alignment summary
Variant summary with annotation
Coding and non-coding variant reports
VCF pre-processing tailored for downstream genetic analysis
Additional option- Comparison against individuals or related reference genomes
Additional option- Extraction of variants for molecular marker development

services.applications: High-depth whole genome resequencing of microbial isolates followed by alignment to a reference genome for precise identification of genomic variation. This approach enables detection of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), insertions and deletions (InDels), copy number variations (CNVs), and structural rearrangements. Long-read sequencing enhances resolution of complex genomic regions and large structural variants. The method is well suited for strain-level analysis, comparative genomics, mutation tracking, and outbreak investigations.

pros: High-resolution strain-level variant detection
Ideal for comparative genomics and outbreak investigations
Accurate mutation and variant analysis
notes: Requires a high-quality reference genome
Use of a closely related reference improves variant calling accuracy
Sequencing depth affects detection of low-frequency variants
Structural variant detection benefits from long-read sequencing
16S/18S-based strain purity testing is recommended prior to resequencing

coverage_guidelines.long_read: 18X-20X coverage optimized for structural variant detection

reports: Sample QC, Library QC, and Summary of Methods
Data QC, trimming, pre-processing, and adapter trimming reports
Reference alignment summary
Variant summary with annotation
Coding and non-coding variant reports
VCF pre-processing tailored for downstream genetic analysis
Additional option- Pathway-level analysis of mutated or modified genes using specific datasets
Additional option- Reference genome assembly from unmapped reads

services.service_name: Whole Genome De novo Sequencing - Large Genomes (>500 Mb)
services.applications: High-depth whole genome sequencing combined with advanced de novo assembly strategies to reconstruct large and complex eukaryotic genomes greater than 500 Mb without reliance on a reference genome. The workflow integrates long-read and short-read sequencing technologies to resolve repetitive regions, structural variations, and complex genome architectures. Suitable for plants, animals, and other large-genome organisms, including non-model species, and supports downstream functional genomics and comparative genome analysis.

pros: Enables assembly of large and complex eukaryotic genomes
Does not require a reference genome
Effectively resolves repetitive and structurally complex regions
Supports advanced functional genomics and comparative studies
notes: Requires high-quality, high-molecular-weight genomic DNA
Long-read sequencing is strongly recommended
High sequencing depth and coverage are required for accurate genome assembly

reports: Sample QC, Library QC, and Summary of Methods
Data QC, trimming, and pre-processing reports
Genome assembly summary with gene detection and annotation
SNP and allele identification results
Haplotype information derived from long-read parsing
GFF3 files, gene lists, repeat element annotations (SINEs, LINEs), pathway assignments, and secondary metabolite coding genes
Synteny analysis and comparative genome mapping for multi-strain or multi-species studies

services.applications: High-coverage whole genome sequencing (WGS) of germline genomic DNA to identify inherited genetic variants associated with hereditary traits and disease predisposition. Sequencing reads are aligned to a human reference genome followed by comprehensive variant calling and annotation. This approach enables detection of single nucleotide variants (SNVs), insertions and deletions (InDels), copy number variations (CNVs), and selected structural variants across coding and non-coding regions. Whole genome germline analysis provides a low-bias, cost-effective strategy for comprehensive interrogation of individual genomes and is the method of choice for discovery and characterization of rare inherited genetic disorders. A purpose-built annotation and prioritization framework ranks variants based on disease phenotypes, accelerating genetic interpretation for clinical and research applications.

pros: Comprehensive genome-wide variant detection
Identification of inherited disease-associated variants
Suitable for both clinical diagnostics and research studies
Supports family-based and population genetics analyses
High sensitivity and accuracy
Variant annotation using curated and up-to-date disease databases
notes: Requires high-quality genomic DNA
Dependent on alignment to a human reference genome
Incidental or secondary findings may occur
Clinical validation is recommended for novel or uncertain variants
Repeat expansions and long balanced structural variants may not be reliably detected

reports: Sample and library quality control (QC) reports
Raw sequencing data QC summary
Reference genome alignment summary
Variant identification and summary statistics
Zygosity analysis and coding vs non-coding variant distribution
Variant annotation and rare variant analysis (phenotype-driven, if provided)
Pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant summary (if identified)
Copy number variation (CNV) analysis and variant effect prediction

services.applications: Targeted sequencing of protein-coding regions (exons) using capture-based enrichment followed by high-throughput next-generation sequencing to identify germline genetic variants. Sequencing reads are aligned to a reference genome to enable accurate detection of single nucleotide variants (SNVs) and small insertions and deletions (InDels). Exome sequencing provides a cost-effective alternative to whole genome sequencing for investigating inherited genetic disorders, population genetics, and gene-phenotype associations, and is widely used as a first-line test in clinical and research settings.

pros: Focused analysis of protein-coding regions
High coverage of genes encoding proteins
Well-established clinical interpretation frameworks
Suitable as a first-line investigation for inherited genetic disorders and population studies
notes: Non-coding regions are not captured
Structural variant detection is limited, especially outside coding regions
Coverage may vary across GC-rich regions
Orthogonal validation is recommended for clinically relevant variants

reports: Sample and library quality control (QC) reports
Summary of methods and raw data QC
Reference genome alignment summary
Variant identification and summary statistics
Zygosity analysis and coding variant annotation with variant effect prediction
Pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants (if detected)
Rare variant prioritization based on provided phenotypes

services.applications: Enhanced capture-based sequencing of protein-coding regions along with selected regulatory and clinically relevant non-coding regions to comprehensively profile germline genetic variants. Compared to standard exome sequencing, extended exome expands target coverage to include untranslated regions (UTRs), splice junctions, and disease-associated regulatory elements, improving variant discovery beyond canonical exons. Sequencing reads are aligned to a reference genome followed by comprehensive variant calling, annotation, and phenotype-driven prioritization. This approach is particularly useful for unresolved genetic cases and rare disease research where standard exome sequencing has limited diagnostic yield.

pros: Broader target coverage than standard exome sequencing
Improved detection of regulatory and splice-site variants
Higher diagnostic yield for rare and unresolved genetic disorders
Suitable for advanced clinical and translational genetic research
notes: Intergenic regions outside the capture design are not sequenced
Structural variant detection remains limited
Coverage variability may occur in GC-rich regions

instrumentation.trio_note: For trio analysis: ~37 Mb target, ~33 GB total data (~11 GB per sample)

process_map: Extended Target Capture and Library Preparation

reports: Sample and library quality control (QC) reports
Summary of methods and raw data QC
Reference genome alignment summary
Variant identification and summary statistics
Zygosity analysis and coding and regulatory variant annotation with variant effect prediction
Pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants (if detected)
Rare variant prioritization based on provided phenotypes

services.applications: Exome sequencing-based genetic analysis of a parent-parent-child trio to identify inherited and de novo germline variants underlying genetic disorders. Protein-coding regions are captured and sequenced for all three individuals, followed by alignment to a reference genome, variant calling, and trio-aware analysis to determine inheritance patterns. This approach improves diagnostic yield by enabling efficient filtering of candidate variants based on Mendelian segregation, making it especially effective for rare, undiagnosed, and early-onset genetic conditions. Trio exome analysis also supports rare variant association studies, transmission disequilibrium testing (TDT), and inference of inherited allele transmission.

pros: Higher diagnostic yield compared to singleton exome sequencing
Accurate detection of inherited and de novo variants
Efficient filtering of benign and non-causal variants
Ideal for rare and undiagnosed genetic diseases
Strong support for clinical interpretation through inheritance modeling
notes: Requires genomic DNA from both biological parents and the affected individual
Analysis limited to coding and captured regions
Structural variant detection is largely limited to small insertions and deletions
Clinical validation is recommended for clinically significant findings

instrumentation.expected_data_output: ~24 GB per sample (~72 GB per trio)

reports: Sample and library quality control (QC) reports
Summary of methods and raw data QC
Trio-based reference genome alignment summary
Variant summary comparing Parent 1, Parent 2, and Proband
Variant annotation and variant effect prediction
Classification of novel, known, and pathogenic variants (if identified)
Inheritance pattern analysis (recessive, dominant, de novo models)
Phenotype-based variant prioritization (if phenotypic information is provided)

services.applications: Comprehensive genome-wide sequencing and analysis designed for hypothesis-driven and discovery-oriented human genomics research. This service leverages long-read whole genome sequencing to enable detailed profiling of individual genomes, including repeat-rich, GC-rich, and structurally complex regions, without PCR-induced bias. The discovery genome pipeline supports investigation of genome organization, structural variation, and genetic diversity, along with germline haplotype phasing, DNA methylation analysis, and phenotype-driven variant ranking. This approach provides deep insights for population genomics, integrative multi-omics research, and exploratory genetic discovery studies.

pros: Enables unbiased genome-wide discovery
Suitable for exploratory and hypothesis-driven research
Detects rare, novel genetic and structural variants
Scalable from small research studies to large cohorts
Supports integrative population and functional genomics
Incorporates epigenomic signatures and advanced variant annotation
notes: For research use only; not intended for clinical diagnostics
Interpretation depends on availability and quality of variant annotations
De novo genome assembly is not a standard deliverable and must be scoped separately

reports: Sample and library quality control (QC) reports
Summary of methods and raw data QC
Reference genome alignment summary
Variant summary including SNVs, InDels, CNVs, and structural variants
Zygosity analysis for coding and non-coding variants (known and novel)
Haplotype phasing using long-read data
DNA methylation profiling
Pathogenic or potentially relevant variant summary (if identified)
Structural variant and repeat-region analysis, including unaligned read assessment
*Long-read local assembly or de novo genome assembly can be provided as a scoped add-on and is not part of standard deliverables

services.applications: Genome-wide discovery of genetic variants and polymorphisms to support studies of phenotypic diversity, trait inheritance, and adaptive evolution. This service enables comprehensive identification of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), simple sequence repeats (SSRs), short tandem repeats (STRs), insertions/deletions, and repeat elements using high-throughput sequencing technologies. It supports applications in population genomics, comparative genomics, breeding programs, and molecular marker development. Optional downstream offerings include primer design and marker validation for functional and applied use cases.

pros: Genome-wide detection of SNPs, SSRs, STRs, and repeat elements
Supports population genetics and comparative genomics studies
Enables marker discovery and marker-assisted selection
Applicable across plant, fungal, and other non-model organisms
notes: Adequate sequencing depth is required depending on the chosen technology
Availability of a reference genome improves SNP discovery accuracy
Polyploid genomes may require higher sequencing coverage
Experimental validation is recommended for functional marker deployment

reports: Sample QC reports and summary of methods
Genome-wide variant discovery results (SNPs, SSRs, STRs, InDels)
Repeat element discovery summary
Flanking primer design and variant site reports
Comparative genomics analysis to enrich SNP/SSR markers by group or population
add-ons: Primer set design for selected markers
Experimental marker validation services

services.applications: Rapid Molecular Diversity Analysis enables fast and reliable assessment of genetic variation within and between populations using high-throughput sequencing-based molecular marker profiling. This service supports genetic diversity analysis, population structure inference, germplasm characterization, breeding programs, conservation genetics, and evolutionary research. It is particularly suitable for characterization of new germplasm and non-model organisms with large or complex genomes, where prior reference genomes may not be available. The workflow leverages discovery and profiling of genetic markers to enable rapid comparison of multiple samples for identifying genetic similarities, differences, and population-level relationships.

pros: Rapid turnaround time
Efficient population-level genetic analysis
High reproducibility across samples
Supports breeding, conservation, and evolutionary studies
Scalable across small to large sample sizes
Does not require a prior reference genome
Suitable for novel or non-model genomes
notes: Resolution is limited by the number and type of markers discovered or profiled
Limited functional or coding-gene inference
Best suited for population structure and breeding group studies
Recommended minimum population size of >24 individuals for robust structure analysis

supported_sample_types: Feather, hair follicle, gut-derived DNA or droppings
process_map: Diversity Amplicon or Marker Multiplex Design

reports: Sample QC reports and summary of methods
Allele call matrix
Population structure analysis results
Individual and group-level clustering and diversity analysis

services.applications: Genetic characterization and clonality analysis of engineered and non-engineered cell lines to ensure identity, integrity, and regulatory compliance. This service enables reliable cell line authentication, detection of cross-contamination, and in-depth analysis of transgene insertion sites using proprietary long-read sequencing-based workflows. The process supports identification of transgene copy number, insertional integrity, and detection of aberrant integration events in complex host genomes such as CHO. Whole-genome SNP and CNV profiling is used to confirm host genome identity, assess genomic stability, and ensure absence of unintended viral integration events. The resulting data support Master Cell Bank (MCB) and Working Cell Bank (WCB) characterization, intellectual property (IP) filings, and regulatory submissions.

pros: High accuracy and reproducibility
Rapid and cost-effective for routine cell line QC
Detects cross-contamination and mixed clonality
Accurate identification of transgene insertion sites and copy number
Supports regulatory and IP documentation
notes: Analysis is limited to targeted and relevant genomic loci
Reference profiles and vector information are required
Not intended as a full genome-wide discovery assay
Periodic testing is recommended for long-term cell line maintenance

additional_requirements: Vector sequence information used for transgenesis

reports: Reporting summary including methods and reference genome details
Identification of transgene integration sites
Transgene copy number and count of integration events
Assessment of transgene integrity (mutations, indels, truncations, deletions)
Host genome SNP and CNV-based similarity and stability mapping
Detection of aberrant or unintended integration events

services.applications: Hybridoma sequencing is designed to recover antibody heavy (VH) and light (VL) chain variable region sequences from mouse, rat, and rabbit hybridoma samples. Hybridomas may express multiple antibody transcripts, including aberrant or non-productive chains. This service combines targeted cDNA amplification with long-read next-generation sequencing to enable accurate recovery, annotation, and classification of functional antibody sequences. The workflow supports antibody cloning, expression, humanization, and intellectual property preservation by ensuring long-term retention of antibody sequence information independent of hybridoma cell line stability. Optional in silico pairing and gene synthesis services enable reconstruction of functional VH-VL antibody pairs for downstream applications.

pros: Accurate recovery of VH and VL antibody variable region sequences
Supports antibody cloning, expression, and engineering workflows
Preserves antibody sequence information for IP protection
Enables detection and flagging of aberrant or non-productive chains
notes: Requires high-quality RNA or DNA input
Mixed or polyclonal hybridoma samples may complicate analysis
Recovered antibody sequences require functional validation

process_map: VH and VL Sequence Recovery and Annotation

reports: Sample QC report and summary of methods
NGS library preparation and sequencing summary
VH and VL sequence summaries with full-length variable region sequences
Clonotype annotation and identification
Flagging of aberrant and non-productive antibody chains
add-ons: In silico VH-VL pairing using internal predictive models
Reconstruction and gene synthesis of antibody VH and VL regions
Functional pairing prediction and prioritization
Custom gene synthesis and cloning services
